top_ideas.idea: Cogito, Ergo Sum (I Think, Therefore I Am)
top_ideas.description: Descartes’ foundational insight was that the very act of doubting one's existence proves the reality of the self as a thinking being. This became the starting point for modern philosophy.

Descartes introduced radical doubt as a method to establish certainty. He systematically doubted all beliefs that could be called into question, including sense experience, in order to find indubitable truths.
key_books: Rules for the Direction of the Mind

top_ideas.description: Descartes proposed a dualistic ontology in which the mind (res cogitans) and the body (res extensa) are distinct substances. The mind is immaterial and thinking, while the body is material and extended.
Descartes claimed that knowledge must be based on ideas that are clear (present and apparent) and distinct (sharply separated from all others). These ideas are the mark of truth and certainty.

top_ideas.idea: God as a Guarantor of Truth
top_ideas.description: Descartes argued that the existence of a perfect, benevolent God guarantees the truth of clear and distinct ideas. Deception is incompatible with divine perfection.
Against empiricism, Descartes held that certain ideas (such as the idea of God, mathematical truths, and the self) are innate and not derived from experience. They are implanted by God in the mind.
Descartes believed that the natural world should be understood in terms of mathematics and geometry. Physical phenomena could be explained mechanistically using mathematical laws.

Descartes described animals and the human body as complex machines operating according to mechanical laws. While animals were soulless automatons, humans had immaterial minds that interacted with their mechanistic bodies.

top_ideas.idea: The Pineal Gland as Mind-Body Interface
top_ideas.description: Descartes speculated that the pineal gland was the site where the immaterial mind interacted with the material body—a proposed solution to the interaction problem of dualism.
Descartes aimed to establish philosophy on a secure foundation by identifying self-evident truths (like the cogito) and building knowledge deductively from these foundations.
key_books: Rules for the Direction of the Mind
